newsitem.title: UK: Merrill Lynch lowers aluminium/nickel forecasts.
newsitem.headline: Merrill Lynch lowers aluminium/nickel forecasts.

text.p: Broker Merrill Lynch and Co has made major revisions to its average price forecasts for aluminium and nickel for 1996 and 1997, but raised its ideas for copper this year.
In its latest monthly report Merrill cut its 1996 average price for aluminium to 71 cents/lb from 74 cents, and dropped six cents off its 1997 price to 79 cents.
This is because consumption, notably in Europe, has been much less than anticipated this year, resulting in high stocks being carried over into 1997.
In nickel, Merrill has lowered this year's forecast by nine cents to 347 cents/lb, and slashed its 1997 forecast by 50 cents to 400 cents/lb.
This reflects nickel demand this year falling by around 2.5 percent, leaving the market roughly in balance, compared with previous estimates of a supply deficit.
In copper, Merrill raised its 1996 average forecast by five cents to 105 cents, as there has been fund short-covering and and good consumer interest for 1997 and even 1998 material.

However, 1998 as a whole could see copper prices at 70/75 cents/lb, due to a build-up in SX-EW (solvent extraction-electrowon) production, rapid increases in mine production, often ahead of schedule, and as much of this will be over and above initial name-plate levels.
